_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.
This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, SunWest Fruit Company has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 SunWest Fruit Company, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that SunWest Fruit Company has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name               | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)
South System                 Anhydrous Ammonia                 30,000
West System                  Anhydrous Ammonia                 20,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public

safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Descriptions

SunWest Fruit Company operates a commercial cold storage for citrus products in Parlier, CA. The facility has two ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

P1 South System
(1) Bin Room
(2) Hydrocoolers
(3) Rooms
(2) Precoolers
(1) Hallway
(4) Degreening Rooms

P2 North System
(8) Rooms
(1) Loading Dock
(10) Conditioning Rooms

The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation. The conditioning room coils, degreening room coils, and hallway north coil are DX air-cooling evaporators.

The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly adjacent to each machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:
P1 Machinery Room
(2) Reciprocating compressors
(3) Screw compressors
(5) Oil separators
(1) Liquid transfer vessel
(1) Main suction accumulator
Condenser Area
(3) Evaporative condensers
(2) High pressure receivers
Bin Room
(2) Accumulators
(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)
Hydrocooler
(2) Accumulators
(8) Water-cooling evaporators (bare coil)
Storage 1
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)
Storage 2
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)
Storage 3
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)
Precool A
(2) Accumulators
(6) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)
Precool B
(2) Accumulat

ors
(6) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Hallway South
(1) Accumulator
(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)
Hallway North
(1) DX Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)
Degreening Room 1
(1) DX Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)
Degreening Room 2
(1) DX Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)
Degreening Room 3
(1) DX Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)
Degreening Room 4
(1) DX Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)
P2 Machinery Room
(1) Reciprocating compressor
(2) Screw compressors
(3) Oil separators
(2) Plate and shell oil coolers
(1) Thermosyphon vessel
(2) Liquid transfer vessels
(1) Main suction accumulator
Condenser Area
(1) Evaporative condenser
(1) Controlled pressure receiver
Room A
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)
Room B
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)
Room C
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)
Room D
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)
Storage 4
(1) Accumulator
(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Storage 5
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)
Storage 6
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)
Storage 7
(1) Accumulator
(5) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)
Loading Dock
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling suspended)
Conditioning Rooms 1-10
(10) DX Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling suspended)

Each flooded system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which

is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the thermosyphon vessel (only P2) and then to the high pressure receiver/controlled pressure receiver.

Each system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the ammonia diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 

There are two ammonia detectors installed inside each refrigeration machinery room. One sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate the mechanical ventilation system at a normal rate of 20 air changes per hour and activate an audible alarm and strobe. In addition, the same sensor is set at 150 ppm, which will activate the mechanical ventilation system at an emergency rate of 30 air changes per hour and activate an audible alarm and strobe. The second sensor is set at 15,000 ppm, which will shut down all refrigeration machinery inside the refrigeration machinery room and activate an audible alarm and strobe. Also, each refrigerated area for both processes is equipped with a standalone ammonia detector, which is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm and will activate an audible alarm and strobe.

An emergency control box is installed on the north exterior wall of the south refrigeration machinery room and the north exterior wall of the north refrigeration machinery room. Each box contains three valves. The high and low side of the system each have a valve that would discharge to the ammonia diffu

sion tank. The connecting pipe between the high and low side has one equalizer valve that would equalize the system.
Each ammonia refrigeration system at SunWest Fruit Company consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.  As such, each refrigeration system at SunWest Fruit Company is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

SunWest Fruit Company has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the SunWest Fruit Company facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

SunWest Fruit Company has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

SunWest Fruit Company's emerge

ncy action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR §3220
- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR §1910.38 

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

SunWest Fruit Company has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, SunWest Fruit Company continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved SunWest Fruit Company's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that SunWest Fruit Company's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

SunWest Fruit Company has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, SunWest Fruit Company has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with

RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, SunWest Fruit Company now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for SunWest Fruit Company employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program SunWest Fruit Company will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
